PostValue.explanation: This is a practical, well-trodden comms & marketing playbook tailored to EA orgs. It’s useful and actionable for organizations wanting to increase awareness, fundraising, recruitment, and influence — so it can materially improve how effectively some EA projects achieve their aims, but it isn’t a novel or foundational idea for EA theory or strategy. If true and adopted, it yields moderate organizational upside; if false or poorly executed, the harm is limited (wasted resources or lower ROI). For general humanity it’s of minor importance — broadly useful to many organizations but not consequential at a societal or existential scale.

PostAuthorAura.explanation: I do not recognize Danielle MacLean as a known figure in the EA/rationalist community or as a public intellectual up to my 2024-06 cutoff. There are no prominent EA publications, talks, or widespread citations under that name in my training data; the name may be a pseudonym or a private/obscure author. If you can provide links or context (works, affiliations), I can reassess.

PostClarity.explanation: Strengths: Well-structured and easy to follow — clear TL;DR, a simple 4-part framework, concrete examples, and practical next steps. Argument is direct: comms/marketing can amplify impact and here’s a template to do it. Weaknesses: A bit long and promotional (multiple external links and CTAs) with some mild jargon (P-E-S-O) and repetition; could be tighter and slightly more tailored to EA audiences.

PostNovelty.explanation: This is essentially a standard marketing/communications playbook (Research → Analyze → Strategize → Measure, personas, funnels, P-E-S-O, benchmarking, experimentation) applied to EA organizations. EA readers will recognize the concepts and many EA orgs have already discussed or implemented similar approaches, so it’s only slightly novel in tailoring and framing for EA. For the general public it’s very common business advice that most marketers or managers have encountered, so it’s not original.

PostInferentialSupport.explanation: Strengths: The post presents a clear, logical, and well-structured four-step framework (research, analyze, strategize, measure) that aligns with standard marketing best practices; it acknowledges trade-offs (when not to invest) and gives practical, actionable suggestions. Weaknesses: It offers almost no empirical evidence that this specific approach improves impact for EA organizations — examples are hypothetical, benchmarks cited are generic marketing references, and there are no EA-specific case studies, outcome metrics, or controlled comparisons. Potential conflict of interest (the author runs a consultancy offering services) is not addressed. Overall, the reasoning is sound and usable as a playbook, but its claims about maximizing impact lack strong, relevant empirical support.

PostExternalValidation.validation_notes: Most of the post’s factual foundations are verifiable and well-supported. The author’s site and pages (the 4‑part template, PESO, buyer‑persona, measurement advice) exist and match the post; the cited benchmark resources (WordStream Google Ads, Josiah Roche conversion-rate summary, HubSpot email benchmarks) are real industry references; academic and sector evidence supports the claim that marketing/comms can produce measurable awareness, behaviour change, and fundraising effects. Evidence also shows Effective Altruism organisations have recently been investing more in communications capacity (e.g., CEA hiring a Head of Communications and listing comms roles on EA job boards). Weaknesses: many claims are prescriptive or qualitative (e.g., “huge opportunity”) rather than precise empirical claims; some benchmarks are industry averages (vary by industry, date, and measurement method) and email‑open metrics have been disrupted by platform privacy changes, so exact numbers should be used cautiously. For a higher score one would want quantitative, time‑series evidence of EA sector spending/headcount in comms and more up‑to‑date benchmark aggregation.

PostRobustness.actionable_feedback:
1) No EA-specific impact measurement or prioritisation guidance — the plan emphasises marketing KPIs (opens, clicks, signups) but doesn’t show how those map to the high‑level EA outcomes readers care about (cost‑per‑expected‑value of a donation, cost‑per‑high‑quality hire, long‑term retention of volunteers, policy wins). Actionable fix: add one short section that (a) shows 2–3 concrete EA outcome metrics (e.g. cost per $ of effective donation adjusted by counterfactual, cost per hire who stays 1+ year, engagement→conversion funnel to take a high‑impact action), (b) gives a simple worked example/calculation, and (c) explains how to use those to set investment thresholds and prioritise experiments (e.g. run small A/B tests with holdouts and estimate marginal ROI before scaling).

2) Missing discussion of ethical and reputational risks — readers in EA care about accuracy, persuasion ethics, attracting the ‘right’ people, and the counterfactual harms of attention diversion. Actionable fix: add a short checklist (one paragraph) of safeguards and tactics to avoid (e.g. avoid manipulative framing, verify impact claims with sources, independently review persuasion materials, track downstream quality of recruits/donors rather than just volume). Give 2–3 concrete examples of reputational pitfalls and how to mitigate them (e.g. PR stunt that attracts clicks but undermines trust; broad recruitment that brings many applicants but few aligned hires).

3) Undisclosed commercial interest and lack of EA‑specific evidence — the post promotes your consultancy and free sessions but doesn’t clearly disclose the commercial angle or provide EA case studies. This weakens credibility. Actionable fix: add an upfront disclosure of any commercial relationship and state whether you have done pilots with EA orgs. If you have outcomes/data, include one brief EA case study or an anonymised result (metric before/after). If you don’t, offer to run a preregistered pilot or suggest a lightweight template EA readers can use to run a 4–6 week experiment and report results back. This will make the advice more trustworthy and useful to EA readers.
PostRobustness.improvement_potential: The feedback identifies three substantial, concrete omissions that matter a lot to an EA audience: lack of EA‑outcome metrics/prioritization, missing ethics/reputational safeguards, and undeclared commercial incentives/absence of EA case evidence. Each point is actionable and could be fixed with short additions that materially improve credibility and usefulness without bloating the post. These are critical improvements (the post is weaker without them) but they don’t render the overall advice invalid, so a top score isn’t warranted.
